qas.question: Who put a stop to the lack of law and presence of disorder in post-Revolutionary France?
Napoleon's decision to reinstate what practice in France's overseas colonies has caused controversy regarding his reputation?
Who considered Napoleon to be a tyrant and a usurper?
Napoleon's role in which revolution has caused controversy regarding his reputation?
Who charge that Napoleon was untroubled by the prospect of war and death for thousands?

context: <a0_0>Napoleon<a0_0/> ended lawlessness and disorder in post-Revolutionary France. He was, however, considered a tyrant and usurper by <a2_0>his opponents<a2_0/>. <a4_0>His critics<a4_0/> charge that he was not significantly troubled when faced with the prospect of war and death for thousands, turned his search for undisputed rule into a series of conflicts throughout Europe and ignored treaties and conventions alike. His role in <a3_0>the Haitian Revolution<a3_0/> and decision to reinstate <a1_0>slavery<a1_0/> in France's oversea colonies are controversial and have an impact on his reputation.
